Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 06:45AM - edited Jul 30, 2008 08:42AM by BikerChick Deb, I, too, am another TAC "consumer".  I completed tx #2 this past Thursday.  Have to say that tx #1 for me was the worst.  Guess it was a combination of anxiety, body getting adjusted or whatever.  This last treatement was much better.  I agree with all those that have posted before.  My "worst" days are 3 - 5.  Feelings of being super fatigued - just want to sleep all the time.  I have continued to work full-time.  Had tx this past Thursday - worked all day on Friday (thx to the steriod buzz), did minimal stuff at home Sat & Sun and then worked all day on Monday.  Yesterday I felt about 80% normal.  Today I feel about 95% normal.  The next two weeks will be "normal" for me and I will do, eat, play and work just like I always did.  I would have to say that my biggest SE was the constipation/diarrhea - especially with the first tx.  This tx was sooooo much better as I knew what to expect and how to address it ahead of time.  So, it is a learning experience. Everyone is different and everyone handles things on different levels. Feel free to PM if you want more info on my SE and ways to combat them. TAC is difficult, BUT it is do-able. And remember- the usual regimen is every three weeks for 6 cycles compared to the regimen of AC x 4 every two weeks then T x 12 every week.  Good Luck with your decision and do what is right for YOU as you are the one who has to live this! Donna    TAC -  tx #2 - 07/24/08  tx #3 - 08/14/08

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2008 09:51AM BikerChick wrote: Elizabeth - relax, your hair will come out gradually.  My first treatment of TAC was on July 2.  On day 13, last Monday, I noticed more hair than normal on my hands/fingers while fixing my hair in the morning.  Each day there was a little more to come out.  It was like a general "thinning" of my hair, not bald patches.  By Friday, it was getting real thin and every time I touched my hair I would get more and more.  So... the DH and I had a few drinks and we "hand combed" my hair until all that remained was some very fine almost white hairs left.  I then had him buzz my head.  Yes, it was sad and yes I shed some tears, but I am moving on.   I, like Otter, did not buy a wig.  I am using my do-rags and scarves.  When my hair started to come out , my scalp did not hurt or get tight, it just kind of had an itch to it more than anything.  Remember, it's only hair and it WILL grow back.  Just think of it as a temporary battle wound in the war against bc. Donna   1st TAC - July 2;   2nd TAC - July 24
